title: Asymmetric Mixed Hearing Loss with History of Modified Radical Mastoidectomy
chief_complaint: I am here for my regular hearing monitoring. I wear a hearing aid in my right ear, but I haven't been able to wear one in my left ear due to discomfort.

problem_summary.course: Gradual progression bilaterally; stable thresholds compared to previous test 2 years ago.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Physical and auditory discomfort with previous left hearing aid trial.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Relies on right ear amplification; left ear has poor speech recognition.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Monitor hearing sensitivity and maintain communication ability.

history.present_illness: Patient presents for regular monitoring; last test was two years ago. Hearing loss has progressed gradually.
history.otologic_history: Multiple otosurgeries on the left ear. First surgery ~50 years ago; modified radical mastoidectomy ~30 years ago. Follows up every 6 months with otology for mastoid cavity bowl cleaning.
history.prior_management: Currently uses amplification in the right ear. Tried amplification in the left ear ~10 years ago but the trial was unsuccessful due to physical and auditory discomfort.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Slight sloping to mild mixed loss (250-1000 Hz) sloping to moderate-to-severe sensorineural loss (2000-8000 Hz). Left ear: Moderate sloping to severe mixed loss (250-2000 Hz) sloping to profound (3000-8000 Hz) with no measurable response at 4-8kHz. Masking dilemma noted for right bone conduction.

numeric_results.Masking_Note: CNM (Could Not Mask) for right bone conduction thresholds due to over masking.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear SRT agrees with PTA; WRS is normal (100%). Left ear SRT agrees with PTA; WRS is poor (50%). Patient unable to tolerate presentation levels >95 dB HL in left ear.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Immittance testing was not measured due to surgical history.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient exhibits an asymmetric hearing loss. The right ear shows a mixed low-frequency loss sloping to a severe sensorineural high-frequency loss with excellent speech recognition. The left ear, status post-mastoidectomy, presents with a moderate-to-severe mixed loss sloping to profound, with poor word recognition ability. Results are stable compared to prior testing.
counseling_points: Your hearing has changed slightly over time but is stable compared to your last test two years ago.
Continue using the hearing aid in your right ear as it provides significant benefit.
Given the severity of loss and poor clarity in the left ear, plus your history of discomfort, fitting that ear is challenging.
However, we can reconsider a trial of amplification for the left ear if you are willing, or discuss Hearing Assistive Technology (HAT) to help in specific situations.
Please continue your 6-month follow-ups with the otologist to keep the mastoid cavity clean.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is accustomed to their hearing loss and diligent about medical follow-up.
You rely heavily on your right ear.
If asked about the left ear hearing aid, express hesitation due to past physical pain or loud sound discomfort.
